YhaJ is a member of the LysR protein family. It was previously associated with regulation of virulence in an enterohemorrhagic
(EHEC) strain
Recently, its capability to bind to the promoter regions of several genes in
and regulate their activity has been demonstrated
IHF, "
ntegration
ost

actor," is a global regulatory protein that helps to maintain DNA architecture. It binds and bends DNA at specific sites. IHF plays a role in DNA supercoiling and DNA duplex destabilization and affects processes such as DNA replication, recombination, and the expression of many genes

IHF is highly abundant in the cell. Its total intracellular concentration varies with growth rate and is higher in exponential phase, with 6,000 dimers per cell, than in stationary phase (3,000 dimers per cell)

IHF acts mostly as an accessory factor, stabilizing a correct nucleoprotein complex. For example, IHF was originally found to be required for the site-specific recombination of phage λ with the chromosome
For this, IHF stabilizes the bending of the DNA to facilitate binding of the bivalent integrase molecules
As another example, IHF stimulates transcription at σ
-dependent promoters. Here, IHF acts to facilitate the formation of the loop between the upstream bound activator and the σ
holoenzyme

Like HU, IHF plays a role in polyamine-dependent DNA condensation. The binding to low-affinity sites and introduction of sharp bends in chromosomal DNA promote the formation of rod-like condensed structures in chromosomal DNA
IHF is a heterodimer consisting of the two subunits, IhfA (HimA) and IhfB (HimD, Hip), that share about 25% amino acid identity
The structure of IHF bound to DNA has been solved
It binds tightly to DNA regions of about 40 bp carrying the 13-bp consensus sequence with A/T-rich elements upstream of the core consensus sequence.
IHF makes no contact with the major groove and only a few contacts with the minor groove

Therefore, specificity is believed to be due to the sequence-dependent structural parameters of the DNA, where A/T-rich regions play an important role. The bend angle induced by IHF is approximately 160°

IHF is necessary for the induction of arginine- and lysine-dependent acid resistance (AR) via both transcriptional and translational controls of gene expression, as IHF activates expression of a specific set of genes involved in survival at extremely acidic pH
An increase in MgCl
concentration changes¿¿the way IHF binds to DNA, from bending to folding. This interaction is not¿¿affected¿¿by pH or temperature changes
The HU protein is a small DNA-binding protein that is considered a global regulatory protein and shares properties with histones, which play an important role in nucleoid organization
and regulation
.   HU is a heterodimer formed by an α-subunit and a β-subunit, which are encoded by the
and
genes, respectively
and are differentially stimulated during cold shock

HU is a transcriptional dual regulator. HU-1 (HupB) and HU-2 (HupA) are closely related but differ by 28 residues, and they have a high content of hydrophobic residues represented mostly by alanine. There is no sequence homology between the proteins HU-1 and HU-2 compared to any of the five histones of different eukaryotes studied
HU forms  high-affinity complexes with DNA containing sharp bends, kinks, branched and bulged structures, or single-strand breaks and loops
Three dimeric forms of HU exist in
: two homodimers, EcHUα
and EcHUβ
, and a heterodimer, HUαβ
All these forms are in thermal equilibrium between two dimeric conformations (N
↔I
) that vary in their secondary structure content
Based on NMR spectroscopy, it was revealed that the
and
genes code for the EcHUα and EcHUβ polypeptide chains, respectively (70% identity, 90% homology)
.   Based on high-temperature molecular dynamics simulation and NMR experiments, information has been obtained about the structural and dynamic features at the atomic level for the N
↔I
thermal transition of the EcHUβ
homodimer
A 3D model has been proposed for the major I
conformation of EcHUβ
The crystal structure of the DNA-HUαβ complex has been resolved
In the presence of poly(P), HupA is efficiently degraded by Lon
The presence of HU depends on the phase of growth
and it is distributed uniformly in the nucleoid
Currently, no inducer for this regulator has been reported in the literature.  A
mutation affected the production of cell surface structures in strains lacking a
gene
HU belongs to a family of DNA architectural proteins and acts mostly as a regulatory or accessory factor, stabilizing a correct nucleoprotein complex
For example, HU introduces negative supercoiling in covalently closed circular DNA in the presence of topoisomerase I
Negative supercoiling induces significant looping under any appreciable tension
The HU protein has been shown to be involved in DNA replication
and the formation of transcription foci
and it modulates the binding of IHF to oriC
and stabilizes the DnaA oligomer bound to oriC
As another example, HU is required for the expression of σ
factors

Recently, Oberto et al. showed that HU also plays an important role in the regulation of many genes in response to environmental changes and adaptation to stress, including changes in osmolarity, acid stress, SOS induction, and anaerobiosis
HU binds DNA without sequence specificity and with low affinity, but at low concentrations HU induces bends and at high concentrations HU induces the formation of rigid filaments
. The binding of this protein is destabilized when the tension of the double helix increases

Relationships between HU/IHF sequence, DNA-binding properties, and other protein features were identified based on sequence comparisons of thousands of known histone-like proteins from diverse bacterial phyla, in addition to a comparative modeling that demonstrated that HU protein 3D folding is even more conservative than the HU sequence
The effects of HU protein enhancements on DNA flexibility and the cyclization rate have been determined, based on a Monte Carlo approach, by Czapla et al.

FrmR is a formaldehyde sensor
and a member of the CsoR/RcnR family of transcriptional repressors
. It was first identified by Herring and Blattner (2004) as a negative regulator of the
operon; its function can be inactivated by suppression of its amber stop codon
expression is induced by formaldehyde, but not by
-nitrosoglutathione
.  Expression of
is induced 41-fold upon exposure of cells to the biocide polyhexamethylene biguanide.  Overexpression of
has no effect on the MIC of polyhexamethylene biguanide
.  Based on
and

experiments, it was shown that FrmR senses the toxic chemical formaldehyde directly, with no metal dependence, via the formation of intersubunit methylene bridges between adjacent Pro2 and Cys35 residues
.  The X-ray structure of the formaldehyde-treated FrmR tetramer has been identified at 2.7-Å resolution
.  FrmR is conserved among the Proteobacteria
.  FrmR: "
o
aldehyde-induced
egulator"
The "
fflux
egulator," CueR, regulates genes related to the primary copper homeostasis system
, which responds to the presence of copper, silver, or gold ions
. The Cue system is predominantly active under aerobic conditions
.  The crystal structures of CueR dimers bound to Cu
, Ag
, or Au
have been solved

. Each monomer consists of three domains, an N-terminal DNA-binding domain carrying two helix-turn-helix motifs, a central dimerization domain, and a C-terminal metal-binding domain. The DNA-binding and dimerization domains are characteristic of the MerR family of proteins. The dimerization domain contains a 10-turn α-helix that forms an antiparallel coiled-coil with the helix of the other monomer. The metal-binding domain contains an unusual metal receptor site in which the bound metal is inaccessible to the solvent. The metal ion is bound with a linear coordination to two conserved cysteine residues. This dithiolate coordination confers the metal ion selectivity for +1 ions

. The sensitivity of CueR for copper(I) ions is extremely high (in the zeptomolar range), which corresponds to less than one atom per cell. Apparently it is the task of CueR and CopA to clear the toxic copper ions rapidly from the cytoplasm into the periplasmic space
.  CueR activates transcription by overlapping the -35 box of promoters and represses it by binding downstream of the transcription start site
. CueR  binds to a 19-bp sequence containing two 7-bp inverted repeats separated by a 7-bp spacer
.  Binding occurs
in both the presence and the absence of copper ions. Holo-CueR binds more strongly to DNA than apo-CueR and with a higher conformational flexibility
. Both holo- and apo-CueR bend DNA
. The RNA polymerase is capable of binding to the
promoter independently of the holo or apo conformation of CueR, generating two types of interactions between RNA polymerase and the
promoter: one is favored by the holo-CueR conformation to activate transcription, and the other one is favored by apo-CueR to repress transcription
The unbinding process between protein-DNA interactions was studied using  CueR as the model
The formation of permanganate-sensitive transcription complexes requires copper ions
.  CueR, a transcriptional dual metalloregulator, is subject to ATP-dependent proteolysis in the presence of Lon and ClpXP and ClpAP machineries
. Its degradation is not altered by mutations affecting copper binding, dimerization, or DNA binding, but it requires an accessible C terminus
.  Reviews:

_text: The transcriptional activator FUR, for "
erric
ptake
egulation,"  is capable of controlling its own synthesis
and controls the transcription of genes involved in iron homeostasis
and a minor sigma factor that initiates transcription of ferric citrate transport genes in response to the presence of periplasmic iron(III) dicitrate
This regulator also participates in the regulation of transcription of many other genes involved in different cellular functions, including the following: flagellum chemotaxis
methionine biosynthesis
acid and oxidative stresses
metal ion stress
resistance to cobalt and nickel
the tricarboxylic acid cycle
glycolysis and gluconeogenesis
respiration
porins
purine metabolism
2,3-dihydroxybenzoate biosynthesis
and phage DNA packaging
Based on transcriptome analysis, expression levels of a set of genes regulated by Fur change substantially in response to antibiotic treatment
Iron homeostasis influences the evolution of ciprofloxacin resistance
FUR is a transcriptional repressor but also can be an activator; the positive regulation of this regulator  is mediated by the indirect effect of RhyB, which is an antisense small RNA
FUR is a sensor  of  the concentration of intracellular iron, and the genetic repression occurs when the physiological inducer, iron (Fe
), binds to FUR. This cofactor is required for DNA binding
FUR also is considered a  metalloregulatory protein and can sense different  divalent metal ions, such as Zn(II), Cu(II), Cd(II), Co(II), and Mn(II)

Transcriptomic and statistical modeling analyses with Zn concentration shifts showed a transient change in the activity of the iron regulator Fur and of the oxidative stress regulator SoxS; these findings suggest a competitive binding mechanism for the physiology of Zn and Fe uptake
On the other hand, D'Autr¿¿aux et al. showed that nitric oxide, a radical that is potentially toxic, inhibits  the DNA binding of this repressor

In the presence of iron, FUR binds in tandem to possible inverted repeat sequences in the  intergenic region to repress transcription by overlapping the -35 box of the regulated promoter. The FUR-binding sites were previously represented as regions of 19 bp, which were determined by footprinting of several promoter sequences
Different aligments and computational analysis of these sequences showed different overlapping 15-bp sequences: TGATAATnATTATCA, consisting of two inverted repeats of 7 bp separated by 1 bp

Experimental support for this consensus sequence was obtained from footprinting, site-directed mutagenesis experiments, analysis of the affinity and stoichiometry of DNA binding, gel retardation assays, etc.
Currently there are different interpretations and models to explain how FUR could overlap inverted repeats in tandem

Under anaerobic and iron-dependent¿¿growth conditions,¿¿Fur binds to more sites across the genome,¿¿increasing the number of target genes¿¿and its repressor effect. Four operons are regulated by Fur exclusively under these conditions
Strains lacking ¿¿Fur grow slower under aerobic conditions than under anaerobic conditions
, which suggests that Fur is controlled by O
. O
has a direct effect on levels of active Fur
, and several factors contribute to the expression profile of the Fur regulon in response to O
, such as upregulation of FeoABC Fe
uptake under anaerobic conditions

_text: The YafQ-DinJ toxin-antitoxin system was identified by its similarity to the RelE-RelB toxin-antitoxin system
.  Expression of YafQ alone reduces protein synthesis and inhibits growth, and coexpression of DinJ alleviates that phenotype, acting as the antitoxin
.    YafQ and DinJ form a stable complex
which can bind to the
palindrome upstream of the translation start site
.  A strain from which all five toxin-antitoxin systems have been deleted shows no deficiency in its stress response or competitiveness under nutrient-limited conditions
.  However, biofilm formation is affected via expression of the TabA protein
.  A
deletion mutant is impaired in biofilm formation

.  Deletion of any single toxin-antitoxin system encoding an RNase has no effect on persister formation, but deleting ten such systems dramatically reduces persister formation.  Persister formation depends on degradation of the antitoxins by the Lon protease
.  A crystal structure of the DinJ-YafQ complex has been solved at 1.8 Å resolution, showing a YafQ-(DinJ)
-YafQ conformation
.  Similar results were obtained for the proteins from
BL21(DE3)
.  Reviews:
The crystal structure of the toxin-antitoxin (TA) HigBA complex has been resolved to 2.7 Å resolution. It displays a hetero-tetramer (HigBA)
form comprised by two HigB and two HigA subunits
HigA and HigBA autoregulate differentially in vivo. Helix-turn-helix (HTH) folds  of (HigBA)
are responsible for their recognition of operator DNA
MntR, "
ransport

egulator", the primary sensor and transducer of manganese abundance, is a dual regulator that senses manganese and negatively or positively controls the transcription of different genes involved in manganese homeostasis

This protein belongs to the DtxR family. The members of this family have three domains: an N-terminal domain with a helix-turn-helix motif, which binds to DNA; a central domain for dimerization and metal ion binding; and a C-terminal alpha-spectrin SH3-like domain. However, MntR lacks the SH3-like domain
The 3D structure of apo-MntR has been solved. The protein dimerizes via its C-terminal domain. The N-terminal and C-terminal domains are connected by a long α-helical linker
The N-terminal domain is expected to bind two manganese ions per monomer, in analogy to BsMntR from
, which has been crystallized with and without bound manganese
All residues involved in manganese binding in BsMntR ar conserved in MntR
MntR does not seem to be autoregulated
Many iron acquisition genes are derepressed in the
mutant
ZntR, "
i
c
ransport
egulator," regulates a gene involved in the Zn(II), Cd(II), and Pb(II) transport systems
In the presence of any of these ions, ZntR activates transcription of
by a DNA distortion mechanism that makes the promoter a better substrate for RNA polymerase
The interaction of ZntR with Zn(II) has been characterized

but its interaction with other ions has not been described. An inverted repeat sequence of 22 bp, located in the spacer between the -10 and the -35 boxes, has been identified as the ZntR dimer-binding site
The crystal structure of an N-terminally truncated fragment of ZntR bound to zinc was solved at a resolution of 19 Å
Each monomer of ZntR has three domains: a dimerization helix, a signal recognition site and a DNA-binding motif (helix-turn-helix)
Two zinc ions are bound to each monomer
ZntR belongs to the MerR family, and although most members of this family are transcribed divergently from the genes they regulate,
is distant on the genome from its regulated gene

The ClpXP and Lon proteases degrade ZntR, but the regulator is protected against proteolysis when it is bound to zinc and DNA. The ClpXP protease appears to need an adaptor to carry out proteolysis of ZntR
RcsB-BglJ is a pleiotropic transcriptional activator that coordinates regulation with global regulators, including CRP, LeuO, and HNS. BglJ-RcsB is active independently of RcsB phosphorylation
Regulation by heteromeric transcription factors is a rare event in the bacterial word
A 20-bp consensus sequence motif has been proposed for RcsB-BglJ based on analysis with the MEME suite

RcsB-BglJ acts antagonistically as well as synergistically with additional transcription factors, such as HNS, CRP, and LeuO. Activation by RcsB-BglJ occurs both at non-HNS-repressed promoters as well as at promoters repressed by HNS and/or StpA

_text: The FlhD and FlhC proteins are transcriptional factors that form heterohexamers  (FlhD
C
. The complex transcription factor is the principal regulator of bacterial flagellum biogenesis and swarming migration
. This heteromeric regulator activates class II genes involved in the flagellar basal body
,  proteins of the export machinery, the flagellar σ subunit (FliA), and its anti-σ factor, FlgM
. Currently, no inducer for this regulator has been reported in the literature. A microarray analysis showed that the master regulator, FlhD
C
, regulates several nonflagellar genes, but the direct effect has not been determined.   FlhD and FlhC are part of the unusual
operon that encodes two transcriptional regulators
. The expression of the
master operon is multirregulated by several systems, including those that respond to high osmolarity
, catabolic repression
, quorum sensing
, synthesis of type 1 fimbriae
, the histone-like nucleoid protein
, heat shock, etc.  The flagellar regulator activates transcription of class II genes by overlapping the -35 box of the promoters
. The binding targets for the regulator consist of two repeat sequences that possess conserved motifs separated by a 10- to 11-bp spacer

.   The subunit FlhD is comprised of  two domains: the N-terminal domain is responsible for dimerization and the C-terminal is a highly flexible domain containing the DNA-binding (helix-turn-helix motif) region
. The subunit FlhC is comprised of two domains; arrangement of the domains is unique in the FlhC family
. The crystal structure of FlhDC has been solved to 3 Å resolution
.  The FlhDC regulon was comprehensively mapped using ChIP-seq and RNA-seq

_text: RcsB protein for "
egulator
apsule
ynthesis
," is a response regulator that belongs to the multicomponent RcsF/RcsC/RcsD/RcsA-RcsB phosphorelay system
and is involved in the regulation of the synthesis of colanic acid capsule, cell division, periplasmic proteins, motility, and a small RNA

[1999391][7534408][8763957][12864862][16000739][16776655][19026860]|.   The response regulator RcsB is the principal regulator of this system and it may form complexes with the RcsA auxiliary protein (forming a heterodimer)
, while RcsB activates the others genes independently (in the form of a homodimer)

.  RcsC is a sensor histidine kinase and is known to be a transmembrane protein composed of three domains: the external sensory domain (amino terminal), a cytoplasmic transmitter domain (carboxyl terminal), and a transmembrane hydrophobic central domain (unknown function). RcsC is a membrane-bound protein that is able to sense extracellular changes in temperature, overexpression of membrane protein, and osmolarity
. RcsC is a hybrid kinase, contains both an H1 and D1 domain, and is able to transfer phosphoryl groups to the conserved Hpt domain of RcsD
. RcsC and RcsD are inner membrane proteins that are involved in the phosphorylation of RcsB in response to environmental signals
. Once phosphorylated, the RcsB protein is a positive regulator and it increases the affinity for the specific DNA-binding sites and controls the transcriptional expression of operons
. It is believed that  RcsF protein may also be capable of phosphorylating RcsB.  Lys180 is a residue that is located within the predicted DNA-binding motif for RcsB transcriptional regulation.
-Lysine modulates through this residue the RcsB-dependent repression of the
operon

.   The RcsB/RcsA complex has major affinity for binding sites of which RcsB is only one. The homodimers of RcsB activate transcription, interacting with the RNA polymerase, by overlapping the -35 box of the core promoter; the central position of the binding site is located near bp -41.5
. The formation of heterodimers between RcsB and the RcsA auxiliary protein stabilizes interactions with the distant binding sites
.  The amount of RcsA protein is limited both by its rapid degradation by two proteases, Lon and ClpYQ, and by its low level of synthesis

.   RcsB, which belongs to the two-component family, shows a helix-turn-helix motif for interaction with DNA in the C-terminal domain, while the the N-terminal domain is typical of the response regulator
.  Reviews:

_text: The response regulator OmpR, for "
uter
embrane
rotein
egulator,"
belongs to the two-component system EnvZ/OmpR

EnvZ is an osmosensor histidine kinase and is known to be a transmembrane protein composed of three domains: an external sensory domain (amino terminal), a cytoplasmic transmitter domain (carboxyl terminal), and a transmembrane hydrophobic central domain

The sensor domain responds to changes in extracellular osmolarity. EnvZ and OmpR comprise a signal transduction system where the signal generated by the periplasmic receptor affects through a protein-protein interaction the EnvZ cytoplasmic component, which is transmitted via autophosphorylation of histidine kinase to the response regulator OmpR
OmpR is localized preferentially at the nucleoid edges and close to the cell membrane under low-salt and acidic conditions
Phosphorylated OmpR controls the transcriptional expression of several genes and operons whose products are involved in adaptation to changes in osmolarity, such as major outer membrane porins
, and it negatively regulates the expression of flagella
promotes biofilm formation
increases curli gene expression
increases expression of several drug exporter genes
and confers increased beta-lactam resistance
among other effects
When the genes
or
are overexpressed, the curli number is increased, with higher levels found in cells overexpressing the
gene, and there is not an additive effect on the curli number or structure in a strain overexpressing both the
and
genes. In spite of the increase in the number of curli, there is no correlation with cell adhesion capability. Additionally, in strains overexpressing
, or both, the growth rate is decreased
This protein consists of two functional domains, the N-terminal receiver domain, which is phosphorylated, and the C-terminal output domain, which binds to DNA and interacts with the σ
subunit of RNA polymerase to activate transcription
The output domain belongs to the winged helix-turn-helix family of transcription factors
Its activity is silenced by the receiver domain, and phosphorylation relieves inhibition.   The crystal structure of the DNA-binding domain has been determined at 1.95-¿¿ resolution
and also has been solved by NMR spectroscopy
In addition, Rhee et al. identified the DNA-binding properties of the C-terminal of OmpR based on chemical shift changes and analysis of amino acid substitutions and base pair substitutions

.  This regulator binds in tandem to sequences that are 20 nucleotides long and possess conserved motifs composed of two 10-bp direct repeat subsites; each dimer binds to one of these conserved sequences
A model of regulation that explains the differential expression of porin genes has been described by Mattison et al. (2002) and by Yoshida et al. (2006)
. The investigators showed that in this model OmpR-P binds differentially and cooperatively to regulatory regions of the genes
and
. Under high-osmolarity conditions,
is repressed by DNA looping while the
gene is expressed, but under low-osmolarity conditions the effects on these genes are the reverse, i.e.,
expression is repressed while
expression is increased

However, a potential mechanism for the phosphorylation-mediated activation of OmpR-regulated transcription follows the same pattern as with other members of the OmpR/PhoB family of response regulators (RRs)
The cross-regulation of OmpR by CpxA, ArcB, or acetyl phosphate results in phosphorylation of OmpR in response to different conditions
Although in both
serovar Typhimurium and

the OmpR transcriptional dual regulator is identical, its expression is regulated differently in the two bacterial species, and there are very large differences in the composition of the OmpR regulon. In addition, the OmpR regulon evolved with different responses and roles in the two species during acid stress

In a genome-scale study based on ChIP-exo, RNA-seq analysis, and DNA motif sequence identification, the OmpR regulon was characterized. A total of 37 genes in 24 transcription units (TUs) were identified to be under this regulons control during osmotic stress (NaCl treatment)
, involving regulation of mostly membrane-located products of the genes
, and
, which are involved in diverse biological processes
.   Based on the phylogenetic distribution of OmpR and its target gene orthologs, it has been determined that the OmpR regulon is conserved within
, i.e., OmpR is highly conserved across species, but genes in
K-12 MG1655 are not, which suggests that other species may have different regulatory networks to cope with osmotic stress

TRANSCRIPTION_FACTOR_NOTE._text: Biotin carboxyl carrier protein (BCCP) plays a central role in the acetyl-CoA carboxylase complex. The overall carboxylase reaction takes place in two distinct half-reactions.  BCCP, which contains a biotinyl prosthetic group covalently attached to a specific lysyl residue, is carboxylated in the first partial reaction.  In the second partial reaction the carboxyl group is transferred to an acceptor and BCCP is regenerated for further carboxylation 324999]|. On the other hand, BCCP amino terminal is able to bind to DNA; this means, BCCP autoregulates its coding  gene expression (the accBD operon)

RacR is an essential transcriptional repressor for toxin genes
and
, and is thus critical for cell survival; these genes are adjacent to and encode proteins divergent from RacR
. RacR's essentiality is based on keeping these toxins transcriptionally silent

MazF is a toxin that is counteracted by the MazE antitoxin
.  The mazEF system causes a "programmed cell death" response to stresses including starvation
and antibiotics
. The antitoxin, MazE, is subject to degradation by ClpP-ClpA protease complex and exhibits a short (30 minute) half life, whereas the toxin, MazF, is much more stable
.    The structure of the MazE-MazF complex is presented at 1.7 A resolution
.  The complex is hexameric and is comprised of a MazE homodimer sandwiched between MazF homodimers
.  It has been shown that the C terminus of the MazE TF plays an important role for MazE by increasing its binding affinity for the palindromic single-site operator
Review:
The transcriptional repressor HipB, for "
gh
ersistence," is negatively autoregulated and controls the transcription of a critical persistence factor
foms an operon with

, and the products of this operon are classified as a toxin (HipA)-antitoxin (HipB) system.  This HipAB system is involved in the high persistence, which is the capacity of the bacteria to survive prolonged exposure to antibiotics
, and Kawano et al. also showed that this system is important for survival during the long-term stationary phase
.   The crystal structure of the HipB-HipA-DNA complex has been solved at 2.68 Å resolution
. The complex is tetrameric and is comprised of a HipB homodimer that interacts with DNA, sandwiched by a monomer of HipA on each side
.  In the HipB-HipA complex, each monomer of HipA interacts with two monomers of HipB

.  The crystal structure of an extended promoter region that contained two operator sites revealed that the interaction with HipB bound to both sites leads to dimerizarion of HipA, which blocks the active sites of both HipA molecules
.  HipB is an antitoxin that counteracts and neutralizes the HipA toxin, and HipA is toxic in the absence of its binding partner HipB

.  Although HipA does not bind the Hip regulatory region, it plays an indirect role via its binding to HipB.   HipB contains a helix-turn-helix motif near the N terminus and is a Cro-like DNA-binding protein.  It binds to four operator sites with the conserved inverted repeat sequence motif TATCCN8GGATA, and its binding occurs cooperatively and almost simultaneously on the same face of the DNA helix.  HipB forms dimers in solution
.   Reviews:

_text: RelB is a DNA-binding transcriptional regulator which belongs to the ribbon-helix-helix (RHH) family of transcription factors
and it is an antitoxin that prevents the lethal action of the toxin
RelB is part of the
operon, which specifies a toxin-antitoxin system, and it is autoregulated by its own products, RelB and RelE
On the other hand,
encodes a cytotoxin that is lethal or inhibitory to host cells
and it also encodes a cofactor that enhances the repressor activity of RelB
The
operon is induced upon entering nutritional starvation conditions, such as the stringent response or acid starvation
while the level of RelB antitoxin is reduced as a result of Lon-dependent proteolysis. Consequently, RelE toxin is liberated, leading to cell growth arrest and eventually cell death
The expression of the
operon under these conditions may have some as-yet-uncovered beneficial function
RelB and RelE form a high-affinity complex with a 2:1 stoichiometry when RelB is in excess
This interaction of RelE with RelB is essential for regulating the expression of the
operon and for neutralizing the toxic activity of RelE
The ReB
-RelE complex represses transcription of the
operon
via strong cooperative binding to the
promoter region
The 24-bp operator contains a hexad repeat (5'-[A/T]TGT[A/C]A-3') that is repeated twice on each strand
The spacing between each half-site was found to be essential for cooperative interactions
between two RelB

-RelE heterotrimers. Only RelB makes contacts to the DNA and the RHH motif of RelB recognizes the four hexad repeats within the bipartite binding site. High affinity for DNA is only achieved in the presence of RelE
which stabilizes the tetrameric form of RelB
When RelE is in excess,
transcription is stimulated
It has been suggested, that excess RelE leads to the formation of a RelE
-RelB
complex that does not bind to the operator
RelB possesses a well-folded core domain at its N terminus followed by a flexible region at its C terminus, a pattern typical of other antitoxins
The C terminus is responsible for dimerization of the dimeric core domain in the assembly of the RelB tetramer
and the N terminus is responsible for binding to the
promoter region via its RHH domain
By using a low-toxicity mutant of RelE, RelE
, the protein could be purified for structural studies. RelE
exhibits an α/β-sandwich fold. Its C-terminal helix 4 lies next to a conserved positive charged cluster, the putative mRNA-binding site of RelE toxin. In a complex of RelE
with a C-terminal peptide of RelB (RelB
), this helix is displaced by helix 3 of RelB
, resulting in the neutralization of the positively charged cluster of RelE
The RelB-RelE complex in
is heterotetrameric (RelB-RelE)
whereas in
a RelB
-RelE
complex may form a tight association with two adjacent binding sites on the promoter, which could involve either DNA bending or DNA-induced protein conformational change
Several homologs have been identified on the chromosome of
K-12 as well as on those of other organisms, such as
and
, and in the
plasmid P307
Bacterial
systems are conserved in archaea, such as in
, and
OT3
Alignment of the RelB homologs showed that these proteins are considerably more divergent than the RelE homologs
The sequence alignment of the RelB homologs shows that these proteins are considerably more divergent than the RelE homologs
Mutations in the
gene confer a so-called delayed relaxed phenotype upon host cells
in which synthesis of stable RNA resumes approximately 10 min after the initiation of amino acid starvation
These findings provided the first sign that the stringent response system might be connected to the MazEF and RelBE systems through the translation apparatus

_text: YefM is a transcriptional DNA-binding autorepressor for the
operon. In addition, YefM also functions as an antitoxin to form a complex with YoeB, which is a toxin that is counteracted by YefM antitoxin
YefM can bind alone with low affinity to the
operator, but together with YoeB it has an enhanced DNA-binding affinity compared to free YefM

YoeB enhances the interaction with YefM by affecting the YefM conformation to one that is more favorable for DNA binding and/or by stabilizing the nucleoprotein complex at the operator site and reducing basal expression of the
operon
The
gene is upregulated during growth in biofilms
and
is upregulated in persister cells
it is probable that derepression of
autoregulation occurs in these circumstances in response to an as-yet-unknown environmental or cell cycle signal(s) that interferes with the YefM-YoeB-operator interaction
The operator site 5' of
comprises adjacent long (L) and short (S) palindromes with core 5'-TGTACA-3' motifs with a center-to-center distance of 12 bp
which was suggested to be  crucial for the correct stable positioning of YefM-YoeB at the two repeats
This sequence organization is common in
regulatory regions in diverse genomes, suggesting that interaction of YefM-YoeB with these motifs is a conserved mechanism of operon autoregulation
Nevertheless, YefM originally was described as a native unstructured protein
later it was reevaluated as experimental, and modeling data have demonstrated that the protein is at least partially folded
and dimeric
The YefM antitoxin forms a heterotrimeric complex with the YoeB toxin (YefM
-YoeB)
The tertiary structure of the YoeB toxin and the YefM
-YoeB complex has been described

In the complex, one C terminus in the YefM homodimer is unfolded and the other one shows an α-helical conformation and conceals the endoribonuclease fold of YoeB. Two N-terminal segments of YefM form a symmetrical dimer within the YefM
-YoeB heterotrimeric complex and do not contact YoeB directly

YefM does not possess a canonical DNA-binding motif, but instead a pair of basic residues, R10 and R31, conserved in many YefM homologs are absolutely necessary for DNA binding by the YefM-YoeB complex
The GadE-RcsB-P regulatory complex is a general direct regulator of glutamate-, arginine-, and lysine-dependent acid resistance stress pathways
